Subject: Re: [junit] How do i check if i am getting right output
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=12653864; y=IBXByMbj-DuoownrtkHSDMMLY3TjZXUfWiPoJ8_wUgqKDAvN

Chris Dollin wrote:

> We live in a multiplatform world in which different platforms
> have different conventions for what counts as a "line" in a "text
> file". I'd prefer to be able to write a "text output stream" without
> having to jump through hoops to separate one line from the next
> in my text strings. Similarly I'd like to be able to read "lines"
> from a "text file" without having to dither about how those lines
> are separated.

You can in fact do that. Use XML, or use some other library that 
recognizes \r, \n, and \r\n as legal line breaks. BufferedReader does this.

However, you are incorrect in believing that automatically using some 
"platform default" will give you what you want. It won't. Files and data 
are not to tied to platforms. In 2005 anything that is tied to platforms 
is guaranteed to fail. (OK, maybe not anything, but most things.) Just 
because your code is running on Windows does not guarantee that the line 
breaks in every file you read will be \r\n. Just because you're not on 
Windows doesn't mean they won't be.

--
